text:
what is the right way to add a method to an existing function? I am reading the documentation and apparently all I have to do is just define a new function with the same name but different type signature and it should get added as a method, but if I try and do this for the built-in +, it overwrites + and I can't add normal integers together anymore. I am running

`+(x::mytype, y::mytype) = myfunction(x,y)`

is this the right way to do this?

elements.text: what is the right way to add a method to an existing function? I am reading the documentation and apparently all I have to do is just define a new function with the same name but different type signature and it should get added as a method, but if I try and do this for the built-in +, it overwrites + and I can't add normal integers together anymore. I am running
+(x::mytype, y::mytype) = myfunction(x,y)
is this the right way to do this?

text: You need to specify that you want to extent the `+` function that comes from the `Base` module

elements.text: You need to specify that you want to extent the
function that comes from the
Base
module

text:
```julia> struct X end
       Base.:+(x::X, y::X) = "hello"
       X() + X()
"hello"```

elements.text:
julia> struct X end
       Base.:+(x::X, y::X) = "hello"
       X() + X()
"hello"

text: The other option is to `import Base.+` after which, what you did would work

elements.text: The other option is to
import Base.+
after which, what you did would work

text: I think because + is defined in Base and what you want to add the method from there like what they said

elements.text: I think because + is defined in Base and what you want to add the method from there like what they said

text: Thank you! What is the colon for in `Base.:+(...)`?

elements.text: Thank you! What is the colon for in

text: Thank you! What is the colon for in `Base.:+(...)`?

elements.text: Thank you! What is the colon for in

text:
The colon is to make a symbol of it
```julia> :+
:+```

elements.text: The colon is to make a symbol of it

julia> :+
:+

text: I'm not actually sure how to explain why it's necessary though

elements.text: I'm not actually sure how to explain why it's necessary though

text: I believe it's to prevent the parser from getting confused and trying to do `Base .+ (...)` ie a fused broadcast. The other solution would be to write `Base.(+)(...)` which achieves the same goal

elements.text: I believe it's to prevent the parser from getting confused and trying to do
ie a fused broadcast. The other solution would be to write
which achieves the same goal

text:
Hmm, I do remember reading some examples using the parentheses, but when I tried the above in v1.6 it gave me an error:
```julia> Base.(-)(a::X, b::X) = "bye"
ERROR: syntax: invalid function name "Base.((-,))" around REPL[17]:1

julia> Base.:-(a::X, b::X) = "bye" #this one worked```

elements.text: Hmm, I do remember reading some examples using the parentheses, but when I tried the above in v1.6 it gave me an error:
